comments.author: sbarguil
comments.body:
I believe it’s important to incorporate modern modeling practices and operational realities, especially with the increasing adoption of YANG. Below are some key areas I suggest we consider:

**Use of YANG Data Models**: Address how the use of standardized YANG models affects the manageability aspects defined in RFC 5706, including alignment with existing operational and configuration workflows.

**Impact of NMDA**: Clarify how the transition to the NMDA approach—where intended configuration, applied configuration, and operational state are clearly separated—impacts the way we define and assess manageability requirements.

**State and Operational Data**: Emphasize the need to define how both state and operational data should be exposed and validated within the scope of manageability, especially for troubleshooting and monitoring purposes.

**Reflection of Actual Network State**: Ensure that manageability definitions consider whether the data models accurately reflect the live state of the network, enabling better diagnostics and real-time visibility.

comments.author: sbarguil
comments.body:
We have [RFC 6020](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6020)/[RFC 7950](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7950) that define the YANG language syntax. However, we also need operational and management guidelines—as set out in RFC 5706 and RFC 8407—to govern how a YANG model will run in practice. 

For example, if an asynchronous server implements the model, how does a client determine whether a request has completed or is still in progress? RFC 5706’s review checklist (Appendix A.2) suggests using notifications in the context of alarms and faults. But this is not clearly described for the Service/Network models used for provision.  

The aim is not to duplicate YANG syntax RFCs but to extend them with clear operational requirements once the YANG model is deployed.

comments.author: graf3net
comments.body:
A good example would be

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-opsarea-rfc5706bis#section-2
BGP flap damping [RFC2439] is an example. It was designed to block high-frequency route flaps; however, the design did not consider the existence of BGP path exploration / slow convergence. In real operations, path exploration caused false flap damping, resulting in loss of reachability. As a result, many networks turned flap damping off.


https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-grow-bmp-path-marking-tlv-02#section-2.1
Reason Code (2 Octets, optional): indicates the reason of the path status indicated in the Path Status field. The reason code field is optional. If no reason code is carried, this field is empty. If a reason code is carried, the reason code is indicated by a 2-byte value, which is defined in Table 2.

+------------+-----------------------------+
| Value      | Path type                   |
+------------------------------------------+
| 0x00001000 | Suppressed                  |
+------------+-----------------------------+

Suppressed refers to a path which has been declared suppressed by the BGP Route Flap Damping mechanism as described in Section 2.2 of [RFC2439].
